quoteFirst: It was the first coin he found in his pocket, and the sight of it caused a frown. Confound those Montmartre playwrights! Why was their stupid travesty constantly recurring to his mind? He frowned again, this time at Auguste Comte's smugness, and looked at his watch.
quoteLast: ! It was too late now to do other than write--if he succeeded. If not--ah, well! "Some of them are slain in the flower of their youth.
title: A Son of the Immortals
author: Tracy, Louis, 1863-1928; Christy, Howard Chandler, 1873-1952 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: the enemy’s fire again slackened, and the headmost ship was discovered bearing up. Now the _Constitution_ reversed her tactics, shot ahead, crossed the first vessel’s stern and raked her fearfully, sailed about the stern most and raked her also; then, ranging up within hail on the larboard quarter, she prepared for another broadside, when the last ship fired a lee gun and remained silent.
title: Naval Actions of the War of 1812
author: Barnes, James, 1866-1936; Chapman, Carlton T., 1860-1925 [Illustrator]

title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteLast: steered south-east through an open melaleuca scrub, the soil sandy loam, thinly grassed; acacia, bloodwood, silver-leafed ironbark, and grevillia forming open patches of wood at intervals. At noon turned south, and at 1.35 p.m. camped at a small lagoon nearly dry and half a mile from the bank of the river; a few hills rose close to the south-west of the river opposite our camp, the lower ridges grassy, the higher hills wooded, but not exceeding 500 feet above the plain.
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: In about three minutes the smoke clearing away, we found ourselves abreast of the headmost ship, the sternmost ship luffing up for our larboard quarter; we poured a broadside into the headmost ship, and then braced aback our main and mizzen topsails, and backed astern under cover of the smoke, abreast the sternmost ship, when the action was continued with spirit and considerable effect until
quoteLast: , when the enemy's fire again slackened, and we discovered the headmost bearing up; filled our topsails, shot ahead, and gave her two stern rakes. We then discovered the sternmost ship wearing also; wore ship immediately after her, and gave her a stern rake, she luffing to on our starboard bow and giving us her larboard broadside.
title: The Medallic History of the United States of America 1776-1876
author: Loubat, J. F. (Joseph Florimond), 1831-1927; Jacquemart, Jules-Ferdinand, 1837-1880 [Illustrator]

quoteLast: . "Left Turin, Friday, at 7:20 A.M. "Arrived at Brindisi, Saturday, October 5th, at 4 P.M. "Sailed on the Mongolia, Saturday, at 5 P.M. "Reached Suez, Wednesday, October 9th, at 11 A.M. "Total of hours spent, 158-1/2; or, in days, six days and a half.

author: Statham, Edward Phillips, -1921

quoteLast: ," says M. Dumont d'Urville, "we arrived at the summit of the Chahorra, which is evidently a half-extinct crater. Its sides are thin and sloping, it is from sixty to eighty feet deep, and the whole surface is strewn with fragments of obsidian, pumice-stones, and lava. Sulphureous vapour, forming a kind of crown of smoke, is emitted from it, whilst the atmosphere at the bottom is perfectly cool.
title:
Celebrated Travels and Travellers, Part 3.
The Great Explorers of the Nineteenth Century
author: Verne, Jules, 1828-1905; Benett, Léon, 1838-1917 [Illustrator]; D'Anvers, N., 1844-1933 [Translator]

quoteFirst: The next day the brigade moved out at 4.30 a.m. to march on Shahroban with orders to skirt the town, the Buffs to go round the south side and the Dogras the north. The great objective was a certain nullah, and this was occupied without opposition at
quoteLast: Then another period of monotony set in and until the 18th October the battalion was at Shahroban in Mesopotamia, and that was all its history.
title: Historical records of the Buffs, East Kent Regiment (3rd Foot)

quoteLast: steered 220 degrees over a fine grassy country; at 7.0 ascended a small ironstone hill, from which we observed a deep valley trending to the south-west; to the north and west the country was open and grassy for twelve miles, presenting at one view fifty or sixty thousand acres of fine sheep pasture.
